Translated_Text: What did you (pl) do at the place you went to?
As she has prepared space for it elsewhere ...
Their curse is heavy
After his enemies had taken him ... (misprinted)

When did you buy this maize?
he helps us to distinguish between bad and good
I tell you (pl.) this in particular

This is a matter which will not turn backwards (i.e. is inevitable)

Is she the biggest (=oldest) of your children?
She carried (on her back) a full pot of local beer
It has yielded a fourfold crop
Let us replace him (lit. put another instead of him)
This leaf is yellow

If I don't do it, I'm a fool

He rested beside a well

Oh, you father, who lives in heaven!

Take a seat/chair and sit down

To-day our cat caught a rat
In earlier times my house was here
Very many waves arose
Because the hunger was too much for him ...

Translated_Text: What gives a good life is not abundance of property

Translated_Text: He spent all the money as he liked

without understanding

(Don´t disturb) he´s eating
I do wrong

He is a false man
She keeps quiet

Divide this crop into equal parts

Translated_Text: Give me these clothes for free!
lawless (person?)
without eyes

I bought (it) the day before yesterday
We went directly
He kicked properly
Very long ago
This girl is beautiful

Primary_Text: tee beetto biifi ʔaɗɗannohehu daanni noona
Translated_Text: You girl, be beautiful, he who is to marry you is coming!

Check!

Town is a place where there are active people

Translated_Text: I will come to this office to-morrow
How many "birr" does it cost?
I have no silver
In my body there are bones
Three is a bad number
He scratches his body
We must exclude him from our society (More severe than seera, because he will not be accepted again)
It does not stink
A not grown-up child will creep as far as to the backyard
for a little while
What is there, is a big abyss

Translated_Text: The road with holes in it will be levelled out
Sit down on the leaves (on the floor near the fireplace)
Having chased the calves out, they slaughter them
I have worked for you like a slave
He made pattern on a ´Kil´ (fruit of which the finiinco (drinking-cup) is made
so that their names should be written ...
He carves (threelegged) stools
In flames of smoke and fire ...
The fire is flaming
We don´t inherit it pretending it is custom (right) and law
This custom is not good

The duiker lives in the forest
There is duiker (female) in sidaama

The coffe-bush has got root and started to grow
They are bad children
A woman who makes clothes, is clever
If your eye is evil ...
May soil come to me (used as greeting)
I am very poor

Primary_Text: halaale buutʼeemma' yite diiʃʃo hutʼtʼu ʔaana ʔofolltino
Translated_Text: I will search for the truth' said the bee and sat down on the fence
Because I am building me a house, give me the axe
Why do you become tired when you are threshing grain?
They have not become tired like other men
Because it has tired me, I am resting
Rowing (lit. swimming) as they sat in the boat

Primary_Text: badala daanke kaʔne ʃerko ʔassine ʔinteemmo
Translated_Text: After grinding the maize, we make porridge from it and eat it
Because the sun has "struck" me, I am tired
This bed is good

Primary_Text: konne ʔogoro daammu minira dukke massi
Translated_Text: Carry this sack to the mill
Honey of the earth-bee

Primary_Text: tʼaa mannu ʤilu daasi giddo gamba yino
Translated_Text: Now the people have gathered in the party-tent
They took me, holding me in many places
After separating, one now splits the root (by cutting it 4-5 times)
The town shows how to do business
Sorrow will fill you
Ants have eaten the supporting pole
There are leopards in the forest
We have gradually forgotten (lit: we have come forgetting forgetting)
Who is coming over there?

Primary_Text: ʔatenna ʔane ʔuulla mereero dannu no
Translated_Text: There is a boundary between your and my land

Primary_Text: ʔatenna ʔane ʔuulla mereero danna danninanni heeʔnoommo
Translated_Text: We are making a boundary between your and my land
These nice children came
Her name is Dancille

Primary_Text: ʔisi gede danʧumma loosannohu ʔai no?
Translated_Text: Who exists that does good work like him?
The coffee has blossomed
In that tree some flowers are visible to me

Primary_Text: darabonkera ʔiillannonsaha buʃa ʧʼoe kaʔlineemmonsa gede haʤanʤoonninke
Translated_Text: We are ordered to help our neighbors in bad things which might happen to them
4.30 o´clock
This garment is not white
When daybreak dawns, I will come to you
There he cracked open all by himself, having swollen
The place where one scrapes (ensete leaves)

Primary_Text: fugge ʔamadde, tʼaano leeikki barra dassiɗɗao
Translated_Text: Covering it up, now she grinds it on the sixth day
We pierce daSe (play a certain children's game)

Don´t forget yourselves
Don´t forget the cows
That mountain is not high
The light of the sun was concealed
Be strong! (final greeting at a mourning visit)
Know that he has strengthened his joints!
I will tear down my barns and build other bigger stores
window (lit. hole for the wind)
The boy fell into a hole
Why do you look at us admiringly?
That is a brown cow
I came from the market
To-day is ´dikko´ (the first market day) for the sidaama
These people are not drunk

Translated_Text: The matter amazed them and they did not know what to say

I have an appointment

How many years has she become? (i.e. What is her age?)

To cheat is a crime

The inset palm is cut to a man´s height
The beam did not reach ground (= was too short, did not encircle completely)

I lead the cows around (circulate them) to one place after another
I am clearing forest

I prefer life to death

Primary_Text: mitto ʧʼimeessa manʧo geerʧo doortuhu gedensaanni...
Translated_Text: After they had elected an old men to be elder ...
He told one news item
They told false news
fried fish
The burden/load is not heavy

Primary_Text: konne ʔogoro daammu minira dukke massi
Translated_Text: By carrying it, take this sack to the mill
Come after me
Build the wall so that your bedroom is not seen

Primary_Text: kuni manʧi ʔanga dunkaho ??? (beʧause of illness)
Translated_Text: This man is a slow worker
He is not a kind person
Be satisfied and prosper (greeting to the hosting family)
Those flowers are red

Primary_Text: lobo dirira ʔikkitanno ʤiro duunante noohe

I know everybody
All people eat meat
When the sun is about to rise = immediately before daybreak. (lit. When the (morning) redness cracks …)

My shoulder is thick (broad)
This coffee is thick
And his intestines poured out
To you who are grown-up, I tell you one thing
near a big tree
We are strong for their well-being, i.e.: We strongly promote their well-being
housefather

They teach geography
Check it and evaluate it!
He invited many people to the celebration
When his son married he gave a party
This is nobody´s property
He spent the day thinking about his possessions only

Primary_Text: ʔisi lobo geeʃa diʧʼoiɗanno, ʤooga manʧooti
Translated_Text: He is a silent man, he talks very little

Primary_Text: gordu faʃʃi ye ʔisi ɗaabara faʔnami
Translated_Text: Heaven opened slightly in his direction
I sent out the message that I am well

I broke a pot
After taking away the stick (marrow???) of the leaf, and covering it ...

The father called his servants

Primary_Text: tenne yannara mannu badala faaʧʼiɗanni no
Translated_Text: At this time people are harvesting maize

Coming, when he was far away, his father saw him
We will reveal their secrets

from all directions

Sweep away this dirt
After one has cut it off, one finishes splitting it
They have come to visit relatives

Primary_Text: maalunni ʔilinohe fiitʼikkibinni mitte higge ʔilamootto
Translated_Text: You were borne once in the flesh by your parents

Primary_Text: kuni lamunku ʧʼoi hiitto ʔikkite ʔinsa ʔinsaba fiitʼoontara dandiitanno?

Come to me, for I will give you rest

Translated_Text: Being one who committed adultery, she was despised by everybody

Primary_Text: halaʔladu waai ʔaana haɗɗe wole gooro fula hasiɗɗanno
Translated_Text: Going on to the lake, they want to cross to the other side

Primary_Text: lamu manʧi mulensa furduggi yite fulte ʔurritu

Primary_Text: konni danʧu darginni fulle, ye fuʃʃinsa
Translated_Text: Go away from this good place, he said and chased them out

Primary_Text: goga konne ʔogeessu minira massi ʔitille fuʃʃona

Primary_Text: fultanni fuuttitto woitenni ʔafoommo harriʧʧo ʔagattota

Translated_Text: Regretting that he had given it, the man took his money back
The monkeys ´mobilize´ against the crop
They are assigned to that group
My heart was relieved
May your throat swell (curse)

He even desired to eat the pods of beans
Their burden seems to be heavy on them again
Again she turns it, kneads it and tests it
They have never seen a monkey
He gave him thanks
They spent the night at one place
He lives with God (is pious)

Primary_Text: ʔuddano mooltanno gede rakke rakke galʧi
Translated_Text: Turn the clothes quickly so that they dry

Translated_Text: Illness may have taken someone in our family

Brush off the dust!

After splitting (the stem), one cuts the root loose

We play, having formed two teams

Your kingdom come!
I will work in my field
I did not hear (lit.: I remained without hearing)
Ask forgiveness!
If there is no countryside, there is no city

An ant bit me
Wese is cut to a man´s height
beating their breasts
Children behave like their mother and father

Primary_Text: konni ʧʼoira dae kaaʔlannonke gede halʧoommo
Translated_Text: I want him to come and help us with this matter
after this

Primary_Text: badala gamba ʔassittohu gedensanni ma ʔassatto?

Primary_Text: gedensaanni ʔanninsa kapʼpʼu dudubo ʔammananno gede ʔassite ʔammansiissu
Translated_Text: Afterwards they made their father believe a lie

Those teachers are old people

Primary_Text: ʔisi dae wotʼe ʔaaʔe geeʃʃa ʔagaɗɗeemmo
Translated_Text: I wait until he comes and gives me money

Translated_Text: They caught so much fish that their nets were torn

Translated_Text: In Sidamo many people eat mutton
A sheep eats grass
milk which has become (a little) sour
A cow of Lamiso´s has got a calf, and he gave us colostrum ("raw milk") to drink
She is the most clever among the women (lit. She is sour milk ..
The family are warming themselves at the fire
Having had a quarrel with him, I kept quiet
You may encounter quarrels
She refused, and ran away to play uge
They hated him
A compelling force had entered into her life
This week I will not go to market

Primary_Text: giddo ʃafinʧo hunda hunda kʼasse woɗɗitanno
Translated_Text: Inside she puts a split leaf under, and lays it down

I am threshing the grain
Look (you pl.), the coffee is falling down!

The rain is drizzling
The family is sitting by the fire

He went outside and cried
To the outskirts of the city …
that he should be biased towards them ...
(He) having been (sexually) together with a pregnant woman ...

He is playing a game
If we begin with these plays ...
This play makes me happy
The children are playing in front of the house
Let´s play ball

Translated_Text: We help our father where he plants ensete palms, where one works 'goire'
Put it in that firewood shed
Guard us with your hand
Put (pl.) the supporter on the firewood-place
The sky is getting cloudy

Translated_Text: He throws him to the ground and makes him tumble over
I am thirsty for water
I am thirsty for coffee
I am thirsty for water
The food is used up
He stretces out the skin
Lead the goats into their room

Primary_Text: halaʔlado wai ʔaana haɗɗe wole gooro fula hasiɗɗu
Translated_Text: They wanted to cross the water to the opposite shore
Your house is near the shore
Do you see that mountainside?
I put the maize into the barn
I put the maize into the barn
An ant bit me
The one who drinks water becomes thirsty again
He slaughtered a cow
Is it a custom which the tribe of this country has?
He tore up grass and threw behind him (a sacrifice to avert a danger after hearing a certain bird´s chirping)
Where did you put the kidney of the ram?
Stand up and go!

Primary_Text: kʼaale lobo geeʃʃa gotti ʔassite masakkarattara dandaattaʔikki ʔikkanno
Translated_Text: You may not be able to raise your voice and witness
Put the child to bed in the bedroom
They woke him up from the sleep
A foolish man sold his cow
Hail thee our master

Primary_Text: mannu sagadate bude gudde mininsara bhggu
Translated_Text: Having finished their custom of worship, people returned to their homes
We have gone by (lit. ridden) boat
They complain because their way is difficult
The boy, being angry, speaks with uncontrolled voice
The son of a widow came
Left is better than right
He stands to the left of me
He spliced the burst rope
He spent the time sweeping together excrements (of cows)
Rising early in the morning, do your work

Primary_Text: kʼalʧo gaʔne gutʼtʼoommoha tʼarra kaasa kaaʔleʔe
Translated_Text: I have finished building the ceiling, therefore, come and help me with raising the wall
The bed was uncomfortable (= it hurt me)
The ensete palm declined
After one has cut, pushed and made the root decline/turn over ...

Primary_Text: kʼaakʼkʼoʔya tʼissennase ʔaddis ʔabeba haaɗe haɗummo
Translated_Text: Because my child was ill, I took her along to Addis Abeba
I know that new road
Now you fool are going to die
Because I will come this afternoon, wait for me
They were stupefied (lit. they forgot what to say)
I have forgotten the name of the place
Is there any other matter?
Dansamo and Danchille did not obey their father
He orders us not to tell bad news about them
I came because there is a small matter that troubles me
While he was wandering about together with them ...
He went here and there
Where to are you going?
The dog follows his track
To-day I have experienced a great joy
We waited, and hoped that he would come (lit.: Saying ‘he will come’ we made joy and waited)
He promised to give something good
This play pleases me
He gave us sour milk to drink
A horse that does not eat grass
Wash away this rubbish!
Carry the pods of the barley to the horse, so that he can eat it
Build your house there!
Will he work for less (payment) than that?
Do you see that mountain?
Who is that person coming?
Go to Irgalem and live there
The person who lives there is a woman
There is one matter that I would not despise (= omit to mention)
Those two children came
Take those things and put them there!
After a man has died, he becomes cold
What is the price of this wood?
What is the price of this firewood?
That firewood is better than this
Do you know that tree?
lieutenant, chief of hundred
generous/simple (lit. wide) heart
Digging more than a hip´s depth ...

Primary_Text: isi konni ʧʼoira dae kaaʔlannonke gede halʧoommo
Translated_Text: I wish him to come and help us with this matter
There are snakes in the forest
Come many of you
That field has become green (because grass has started to grow)
He stretched out his hands and embraced him
That is Hankamo´s family
They "step" the hano-dance
But now the time he has is (too) short
The donkeys are walking in front of the man
They do not know the former Sidaama´s games and conversation

Primary_Text: ʔinsaa ledo galanno manni mereero hasse hooggusi
Translated_Text: Looking for him among the people who stayed overnight together with them, they did not find him
I want to have a conversation
House is necessary for all people
Tonight the moon is shining
It was late late (lit. the time had night-ed), and the people needed food

Primary_Text: A: haaro ʔuddano hiɗɗoommo. B: haʃʃu danʧa ʔassoottona
Translated_Text: A: I have bought new clothes. B: Oh; fortunately; you have done well!
Why is it like that?
Likewise, concerning money, I am poor
I have completed most of the work
After separating the ensete layered leaves, one now splits the root (4-5 times)
If a fire starts, my barn will suddenly burn down

Primary_Text: ʔane ledo heebisame lalo gidu giddora nakʼino
Translated_Text: After boasting very much to me, he led his cattle into my cornfield
This boasting is no good
Where do you live?
Is he dead or alive?
The roof is big enough, let us raise (lit. put in) the central pillar
Bowing down, he wrote on the ground
shoestring
Tell me a riddle
Tell me (the answer to) this riddle
How being will this thing happen?
But where are the (other) nine?
One tooth has been broken for me
Don´t break the water-pot
How do you read the law?
What kind of burden is heavy for a man?
How is that tree?
How can the chain break?

Primary_Text: kuni hilʧi danʧa diʔikkinona ʔisi baiʧʧo wole kʼanso
Translated_Text: This supporter is no good and we will replace it with another
My heart has cracked (with sorrow)
immediately
return quickly!
They threw lots
We must treat both cattle and (other) animals well
My neck is thin
How many are your years, i.e. how old are you?
Are you (f) well?
He went into a small boat
They entered the boat
A few students
After piercing the sticks, one spreads the inset leaves
The cows are inside the compound

Primary_Text: ʔalbi yannara hoofaho yinanni manni tenne gobbara heeɗɗanno
Translated_Text: In former times there lived in this country people called "hoofa"
I asked him wether he wanted or not
We wanted you to come but you didn´t (lit. We lacked you)
Take these pots away from the fire
Because you (pl) did what I forbade you ...
Termites have eaten the beam
They share according to his lack
One gets rid of the waste (wasa production)

Primary_Text: ʔati ʔumikkinni horonta sansalete taʔisattara didandaatta
Translated_Text: You (f) are in no way able to break the chain by yourself
I will definitely not come

Primary_Text: ʔisi lali wolu lali ledo dihosanno
Translated_Text: His cattle does not spend the day together with another´s cattle

Man is above everything
I go to the highland
Shepherds came to the compound where he was born
Go (pl.) and guard the cattle
Children look like their mother
A town presents consultations (c. maytake place in towns)
You lead me by advice
She who prepared it in the language of the Amharas (Amharic) ...
A fever has caught me
He who had this, was a little boy
touch your mouth
I have caught a cold (lit.: a cold has caught me)
The purpose of asking him was make him fail and to cause him to be arrested (caught)
attach (connect) with the picture
Then, after that is covered up (with leaves) ...

Primary_Text: kapʼpʼu dudubo ʔammananno gede ʔassite ʔammansiissu
Translated_Text: They made him believe false news, in order that he should believe it
Come concerning a small matter!
I will say like this to myself
Having trodden it, if it is ready for her (to be eaten) by the hand = tested by the hand
5 pairs of oxen
four-fold
Don´t they get double (lit. two hands) in return?

Primary_Text: ʔille ɗibbeennaʔe ʔankaro gotʼummokki gale geleeloommo
Translated_Text: Because my eyes are ill, I spent last night without sleep
A father loves his children
landlord, owner of land
Woe to you rich!
Again, a short time afterwards we usually got reconciled
We said "We shall reconcile" and tried
Next year I go to Arbegona
Fearing his wife he hit the pillow (instead) (proverb)
A woman loves her husband
He did not agree
If it is a place for preparing wasa in the dry season ..

Primary_Text: butʼiʧʧu manʧi ʔulla ʔaɗɗa, bebba ʔassate
Translated_Text: Taking a poor man´s land is doing wrong
He took him with, thinking (planning) to sacrifice him
What do people do at market?
What do you use this wood for?
They marvelled at what they heard

Primary_Text: manʧu laalʧono gideno sagale ʔassiɗara dandaanno
Translated_Text: Man can make fruit and crops his food
Peas are good for food
We help our friends to make their property abound
Easter festival
You gave me a gift
someone´s name
Do you see that house? Yes, I see it
Please, store this money for me
The cattle is down there where there is water
I go to the valley, down where there is water
further down (on a page, in a valley)
Water has collected
drinking water has collected
They did not have a clue
The waves almost swallowed the boat
The shrewd man ´sits´ (lives) there and cheats
Do you know this road?
Did you ever drink milk?
My house is higher than the school (lies above)
Lead the goats into the goat-room
I will give you a good gift
He has started a friendship with him
My friend gave it to me

Primary_Text: ʔado ʃafe buuro ʔaɗɗummohu gedensaanni, ʔereeru gati
Translated_Text: After I had made butter of the milk, and taken it out, the ereero is left over
The king entered (into) the feast
He will understand
Illness may have entered your house
I have caught a cold, therefore I have fever
Fever has caught me
I drank fresh milk together with wasa
The time of thunder is hot
When we reached to there, we did not see her
When the time comes ...
Where does this road lead to?
I believe in him who created the earth and the heaven
Don´t witness against your friend with (in) a wrongdoing (falsely)
He orders us not to rise against them, i.e. stand up and fight them
I am not strong enough (sufficient)
Perhaps they will go to Neghelli

Primary_Text: badala gootaaru giddo mitto diro ʔikkanno
Translated_Text: Maize lasts for one year in the barn
If we are bound by a chain ...
Children behave like their mother
After it had become enough for everybody, much was left over

Primary_Text: kabanni hige saʔanno wai loboha ʔikki
Translated_Text: The river which passes here has become big
Perhaps I will find ...
But even so; even if it might be like this..
Now give me my heritage
We ride (have ridden) a boat in our travel from birth to death
Give birth, get many children and become rich! (part of a blessing said to hosts)
My tongue rejoiced
Because your son came home, isn´t there much rejoicing for you to-day? (= aren´t you very happy?)
Let us seek out a man from among us
Are your eyes well?
A midwife helped her to give birth
When does it suit you?

Primary_Text: ʔalbi manni ʔinsa ʔinsaba lobo maammaʃʃa maammakkanno
Translated_Text: Former people used to tell much proverbs to each other
his own feet
She forgot herself
All right, I buy it
Many people do not eat meat
Water has eaten a man (i.e. he has been drowned in the water)

Primary_Text: goga konne ʔogeessu minira massi ʔitille fuʃʃona
Translated_Text: Take this skin to the ogeessa so that he can make a mattress of it
May Ethiopia grow
draw lots
Your house is new
He spent the time sweeping together excrements
Come and stay in my house
A doctor circumcised a child
Because my cow had broken a leg, I called the doctor

Primary_Text: bero manʧo ʔiltanni heeɗɗe kʼarranteenna ʔogeette kaaʔlite ilʃiiʃʃuse
Translated_Text: Yesterday when a woman was giving birth, because she came in trouble a female "doctor" helped her and took the baby out

Translated_Text: I am trying to learn the language of the Sidaama
Throwing the spear, he pierced a hyena
When she came back to the village, she found people

Primary_Text: ʔumiʔya ʔoosonna ʔolliiʔya ʔooso rosiisammora dandeemmo
Translated_Text: I can teach my own children and the children of my neighbours
If there is no countryside, the town is an empty home
fifty men came
fifty-three

Primary_Text: ʔoosimmate yanna lobo geeʃʃa danʧa yannaati
Translated_Text: Childhood time is a very good time
Are you well? ???

Primary_Text: hakku ʃiimu mini ʔubi wote ʔafoommo
Translated_Text: I saw when that small house fell
The boy fell into a hole (in water)
A father gives clothes to his children
He dressed me in a robe
He cannot buy things from the market
What is this thing?
He has gone out for a hunt
He hunted porcupine
They went to play xuge
To whom did you give it?
I gave it into your protection, responsibility/ custody
first part (place)
After digging at the former place ...
Why did you come?
As he first had thought ...
The girl´s breasts became big (because she had grown up)
He threw the spear and pierced the hyena
Bind the cows in the cow-shed
A thorn pierced me
Those in the circle around Paul
He works the earth (i.e. He is a farmer)
Stop a little
There market is held on Sundays

Translated_Text: He stands higher than me (e.g. on a mountain)
They made her stand in front of all
Fetching the "meeta"-wood and raising it up..
I am ill in my stomach
